newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch closing debt market report.
newsitem.headline: Dutch closing debt market report.

text.p: Dutch bonds closed lower for the third successive day as the strength of the U.S. economy remained the focus of market attention.
The Dutch yield curve also continued the steepening trend of recent weeks as longer paper bore the brunt of selling.
Most of the losses were registered on the opening, bringing guilder bonds into line with U.S. Treasuries, which had traded lower while the Dutch market was closed for Easter holidays.
But the market ended off the day's lows after a bigger than expected rise in the National Association of Purchasing Management's index sparked a short squeeze.
"We had seen such a big down-move in recent days that it triggered a bit of short covering," said one dealer.
Earlier, dealers said they detected some buying interest for mid-curve to longer Dutch paper.
One dealer said Dutch institutional clients were interested in switching into German Bunds when the 10-year yield spread reached 15 basis points, compared with 13 at the close.
"If we do go up from here, people will sell it. The bias is on the downside," the dealer added.
Another dealer said guilder paper maturing between 2000 and 2002 had attracted bids as they appeared cheap.
"If the stock market continues to fall, there will be good demand for short term paper," the dealer added.
The Dutch sharemarket closed sharply down in response to two successive sharp falls on Wall Street.
But a trader said German Bund futures, which generally determine the direction of Dutch state loans, bounced well off support around 99.20 today.
"We have a better opportunity to go up," he said.
